metadata.title: Mastering Python Lists For Programming! | by Bharath K | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Python being the elegant and simplistic language that it is offers the users a variety of options for easier and efficient coding. Python is one of the best programming choices for data science…

all_paragraphs: Python being the elegant and simplistic language that it is offers the users a variety of options for easier and efficient coding. Python is one of the best programming choices for data science, machine learning, and deep learning.
Python is an object-oriented, high-level programming language that was released way back in 1991. Python is highly interpretable and efficient.
Python offers a wide range of library modules and frameworks, making it one of the most compatible languages for constructing machine learning models and working on data science projects.

Python presents a wide array of choices for the completion of each task. It is highly accessible and one of the best ways to get started with programming because it is fairly simple to use as well as quite easy to learn.
It also has a great community with constant updates and upgrades. At the time of writing this article, the most recent version of python is 3.9.

Data Structures are a collection of data elements that are structured in some way. Data Structures are the core of any programming language, and this holds true for python as well. There are many built-in data structures in python.

In this article, we will focus on one specific data structure in python called lists. We will look into the intricate details and understand some of the most essential concepts with respect to these lists. We will also look into the significance of lists for data science and machine learning.

A list is a mutable ordered sequence of elements. Mutable means that the list can be modified or changed. Lists are enclosed within Square Brackets ‘[ ]’. Lists are a type of sequenced data structure with each element in the list being assigned a specific index number by which it can be accessed. Each item or element in a list is separated by a comma. (,)

In this section of the article, we will focus on some of the most important functions of lists ranging from creating lists to adding more elements and even deleting them. Each of these will have a small explanation alongside a code block with its respective output.
Creating a list to store elements.

The above code block creates an empty list. The two lines show the two different methods of establishing this process and the creation of these lists. Both of these methods are completely fine and depend on the user’s preference for how they choose to create lists.
Calculating the number of elements that are stored in a particular list.

The len() is a useful function for calculating the total number of elements in a list. As you can observe from the above code block, there are a total of four strings, and hence the len function on the list returns the output of 4.
Add an item to the end of the list.

The append function is extremely useful to add additional elements to the list. By performing the above code block you are able to compute and add any desired values you choose. The usefulness can be seen more appropriately with iterative statements like the ‘for’ loop.
Extend the list by appending all the items from the iterable.

The extend function helps to combine two lists successfully. The ‘+’ function can also be used for performing this task. The main difference between the extend function and append function can be verified from the above code block. If the append function was used, it would form 2 separates lists. This is called nested lists and will be discussed later in further detail.
Insert an item at a given position. The first argument is the index of the element before which to insert.
The first argument is the index of the element before which to insert, so a.insert(0, x) inserts at the front of the list, and a.insert(len(a), x) is equivalent to a.append(x).

The insert statement will insert an element at the particular index number that is mentioned at the start of the command. The indexing concept is significant and will be discussed in further detail in the next section of the article.
Remove the first item from the list whose value is equal to x. It raises a value error if there is no such item.

The remove() function in lists is used to remove a specified element from the list. In the above code block, if we had two elements named ‘five’, then only the first ‘five’ that was encountered would be removed from the list. The other elements with the same name will remain untouched. Feel free to try this on your own and experiment with it.
Remove the item at the given position in the list, and return it. If no index is specified, a.pop() removes and returns the last item in the list.

Note: The square brackets around the i in the method signature denote that the parameter is optional, not that you should type square brackets at that position. You will see this notation frequently in the Python Library Reference.

The pop function works in a fashion opposite to the insert function. While the insert function adds an element at the respective position that is specified, the pop command will remove the element from the specific position.
Return the number of times x appears in the list.

The count function helps to calculate the number of times a specified element occurs in the given list. If the specific element you are trying to check does not exist in the list, then a value of 0 is returned to the user. The above code block checks the number of times ‘1’ occurs in the list and returns an output of 3.
Sort the items of the list in place.

The sort function is one of the most useful functions in python lists. It is used to automatically arrange all the elements in ascending order. The elements are arranged from the smallest to the biggest, and this is useful for a variety of tasks. If the term reverse is specified to be “True”, then it performs the operation in descending order, i.e., from biggest value to smallest value.
Reverse the elements of the list in place.

The reverse function is used to change the order of the arrangement of the lists. It is important to note that the reverse function is different from the sort function. The sort function arranges elements according to their respective values, while the reverse functions change the order of these elements from last to first.

Note: A few functions like list.copy() and list.clear() have been skipped. To check out all the information and the other possible functions related to the list, you can check out the official documentation.

List slicing is another concept that is very useful to understand. The list elements can be addressed by their index numbers. The 0th index consists of the first element, the 1st index consists of the second element, and so on.
Accessing parts of segments is called slicing. The key point to remember is that the :end value represents the first value that is not in the selected slice.
Return zero-based index in the list of the first item whose value is equal to x. Raises a value error if there is no such item.

The optional arguments start and end are interpreted as in the slice notation and are used to limit the search to a particular subsequence of the list. The returned index is computed relative to the beginning of the full sequence rather than the start argument.
The above code block with the respective outputs is a great way to conceptually understand the concepts of list slicing.

You can also create a list within a list called nested lists. These are usually helpful for matrix operations in machine learning. Similar to how you can call a conditional statement within a conditional statement or a loop within another loop known as nested loops, similarly, a list within a list is called nested lists.

The procedure for creating a nested list is quite simple. This can be either done at the starting by initializing the lists within lists at the time of the creation of the list. Or the other method is to declare two separate lists with variable elements in each of them and then use the append function to unify both of them and frame a nested list.

For a more detailed understanding as well as a simple project on the same, feel free to check out the following article that covers how you can code matrix multiplication from scratch without using any machine learning libraries.

List comprehensions provide a concise way to create lists. Common applications are to make new lists where each element is the result of some operations applied to each member of another sequence or iterable, or to create a subsequence of those elements that satisfy a certain condition.
To understand the concept of list comprehensions with the help of a simple example, let us consider the below code block.

In the above code block, the list with the name “squares” was created. Using an iterative “for” loop and the append function, we were able to calculate the squares of the numbers ranging from one to ten. However, the same problem can be solved in a single line with the help of list comprehensions as shown below.

The above code block shows the representation of how a list comprehension can simplify a code of a few lines to just a single line while getting the exact same output faster. The only issue with list comprehensions is sometimes it could be hard for the reader to understand the code.

By using the approach of nested list comprehensions, you can also solve more complex tasks. Overall, list comprehensions prove to be extremely useful for solving tasks and computations while consuming lesser space and time complexities for general problems. For further usage of list comprehensions, I would highly recommend checking out my article on advanced functions in python from the below link.
Python lists are a valuable resource for Data Science and Machine Learning.

The list functions in python, such as the append function, are highly beneficial while iterating over datasets, and you want to either split the data into positive and negative classes or you just want to add specific elements to the list that you created.

Lists also store useful information and hold essential values that can be iterated over to solve complex tasks and perform computations. You can also make sure of the zip function to iterate two or more lists at the same time to evaluate values.

The other functions such as sort and len are extremely useful for sorting the elements in an ascending order and calculating the specific lengths of the lists respectively. By knowing the length of the list, you will have a brief idea on the number of iterations and the number of epochs you have to run a specific program.

Lists find its uses equivalently in almost every important aspect of machine learning and data science. From computing the hyperparameters in cross-validation to dividing or splitting the datasets to performing a variety of natural language processing tasks. Hence, lists are one of the most essential and significant aspects not only for programming but also for data science and machine learning.

TLDR: The important functions which we use for the list data structure in python for machine learning are — ‘append’ which is used to add elements to the list, the ‘len’ function to find the length of the lists, and the ‘sort’ function to arrange the elements in the list in ascending order. These 3 are usually the most common functions which will be used for lists.

In this article, we have discussed most of the essential concepts of lists ranging from analyzing all the significant commands that are associated with lists to understanding the topics of list slicing, nested lists, and list comprehensions in further detail.

Python lists, as discussed in this article, are an extremely useful data structure. Its use extends from programming to machine learning and data science. The best uses of lists are highly beneficial and are something that is to be considered while utilizing all the resources in python to construct better projects.

If you guys have any queries related to any of the topics covered in this article, then feel free to let me know in the comments below. I will try to reply and answer your questions as soon as possible.
Check out some of my other articles that you might enjoy reading!
Thank you all for sticking on till the end. I hope you guys enjoyed reading this article. I wish you all have a wonderful day ahead!
Love to explore and learn new concepts. Extremely interested in AI, deep learning, robots, and the universe. LinkedIn — www.linkedin.com/in/bharath-k-421090194
